questions.text: Which of the following is false with respect to lifestyle modifications for managing essential hypertension as recommended by AHA 2019 guidelines?
questions.solution:
Low potassium increases blood pressure and hence is not recommended in the dietary modifications. On the contrary, potassium supplementation lowers the BP significantly in hypertensives. It is given preferably by dietary modifications unless contraindicated.

Related Pearl: American Heart Association (AHA) 2019 guidelines for hypertension management

According to the AHA hypertension guidelines, 2019, pharmacologic treatment for hypertension is recommended

  • In patients who have ≥10% estimated 10year ASCVD risk, when BP ≥ 130/80 mmHg 
  • In patients who have <10% estimated 10year ASCVD risk when BP ≥ 140/90 mmHg 

 ASCVD - Atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease

ASCVD risk is calculated using a calculator provided by the American Heart Association.

questions.text: A 57-year-old male patient presented to the clinic for a routine clinical check-up. On examination, his BP was found to be 136/88 mmHg. During his subsequent visits, the systolic blood pressure recorded was found to be within the range of 130-138 mmHg and diastolic blood pressure was within the range of 86-88mmHg. According to the European guidelines for hypertension 2018, his blood pressure would be classified as ____________
questions.solution:
According to European guidelines for hypertension 2018, systolic blood pressure between 130-139 mmHg and diastolic blood pressure between 85-89 mmHg is classified as high normal.

questions.text: An 80-year-old male patient complains of headache and dizziness. His ambulatory BP was recorded to be in the range of  144-152/80-86 mmHg. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
SBP ≥140 mm Hg and DBP <90 mmHg is called isolated systolic hypertension.

questions.text: Which of the following is the gold standard investigation to measure vessel wall stiffness in patients suspected to have hypertension mediated end-organ damage (HMOD)?
questions.solution:
Carotid-femoral pulse wave velocity (PWV) is the gold standard for measuring large artery stiffness due to hypertension.

Long-standing hypertension can lead to structural and functional changes in arteries and target organs like the heart, brain, arteries, and kidneys. This is called hypertension mediated organ damage (HMOD).

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient has grade 2 hypertension. He is also a known case of type 2 diabetes for 9 years. What is the desired goal for blood pressure range in this patient?
questions.solution:
In a patient (18-65 years) with hypertension and coexisting diabetes, the desired goal for systolic blood pressure is between 120-130 mmHg and diastolic blood pressure is between 70-79 mmHg. In patients above 65 years of age, the desired goal of systolic blood pressure is between 130-139 while the desired diastolic range remains the same.

This goal is in accordance with the European Society of Cardiology guidelines (2018).

questions.text: A 58-year-old male patient has been diagnosed with hypertension.  On examination, there is no existing cardiovascular disease, no hypertension mediated organ damage (HMOD) and the renal function is normal. He should be immediately started with pharmacological management if his blood pressure is more than ______.
questions.solution:
In this patient with no markers of cardiovascular disease, no hypertension-mediated end-organ damage (HMOD), and normal renal function, immediate pharmacological treatment is recommended when the blood pressure (BP) is ≥140/90 mmHg according to the AHA and ESH on the management of hypertension.

Guidelines for Hypertension Management:

  • Adults 18–79 y with SBP ≥140 mm Hg or DBP ≥90 mm Hg
  • Adults ≥80 y with SBP ≥160 mm Hg but ≥140 mm Hg can be considered.
  • In frail patients, individualize treatment.
  • In patients with CVD, especially CAD, SBP ≥130 mm Hg, or DBP ≥80 mm Hg.

Treatment BP targets:

  • Adults 18–79 y, primary SBP/DBP goal <140/90 mm Hg; if treatment well tolerated target SBP/DBP <130/80 mm Hg but not SBP <120 mm Hg or DBP <70 mm Hg. For adults with isolated systolic hypertension, target SBP lowering, albeit cautiously.
  • In adults ≥80 y, target SBP/DBP <140/90 mm Hg, if well tolerated

questions.text: A 72-year-old man who is a known hypertensive for 12 years comes for a regular health check-up. On examination, his blood pressure is 172/100 mmHg. His serum creatinine is 1.5mg/dL, urinary albumin to creatinine ratio (UACR) is 40mg/g, and GFR is 49mL/min. What is the preferred antihypertensive treatment in this scenario?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient is hypertensive along with chronic kidney disease. The preferred initial antihypertensive treatment is captopril with amlodipine.

The preferred treatment in hypertensive patients with chronic kidney disease is a combination of angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACEi) or angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs) with calcium channel blockers (CCBs) or diuretics (ACEi/ARBs + CCBs/diuretics).

questions.text: A hypertensive patient is on metoprolol. If verapamil is added, there is a risk of:
questions.solution:
Metoprolol, when added with verapamil, leads to bradycardia with AV block.

Verapamil and β blockers have additive effect on inhibiting SA node and AV conduction, and the combination should be avoided to prevent severe bradycardia and conduction block.

These agents can also have additive effect on decreasing left ventricular function which could seriously impair cardiac output in a patient with heart failure.

questions.text: A hypertensive patient underwent coronary angiography after he presented with chest pain. His angiographic image is as below. What is the preferred drug for the management of hypertension in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above coronary angiogram shows partial occlusion of the left circumflex coronary artery. Beta-blockers like atenolol in combination with ACE inhibitors or ARBs or calcium channel blockers or diuretics are preferred for the management of hypertension in patients with coronary artery disease.

Other indications for beta-blockers are:

  • Congestive heart failure due to systolic dysfunction
  • Post myocardial infarction
  • Sinus tachycardia
  • Ventricular arrhythmias

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with sudden onset of a headache, palpitation, and profuse sweating. He had several such episodes in the past. During these episodes, his BP is found to be high. A 24-hour urinary metanephrine is elevated. What is the most likely etiology?
questions.solution:
The most likely etiology is pheochromocytoma. Patients commonly present with a classical triad of palpitation, headache and profuse sweating. The presence of this triad in association with hypertension and elevated 24-hour urinary metanephrine makes pheochromocytoma a likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient has hypokalemia, hypertension and metabolic alkalosis. What is the most likely etiology?
questions.solution:
Hypertension with hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis is seen in Liddle's syndrome.

Liddle's syndrome (pseudo aldosteronism) is an autosomal dominant condition that is caused due to the increased activation of ENaC channels. This causes increased reabsorption of Na+ exchanged for K+ causing hypokalemia. Increased Na absorption leads to hypertension, and there is also a loss of H+ ion with K+, leading to metabolic alkalosis. It is associated with low renin and low aldosterone levels.

Related Pearl: Renal Tubular Syndromes

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true with respect to hypertensive emergency as per ESC 2018 guidelines?

1) BP >180/110mm Hg
2) Acute end-organ damage is usually not present
3) The initial goal in hypertensive emergency presenting as encephalopathy is to bring down the SBP no more than 30% within 2 hours
4) Should be treated using parenteral drugs
questions.solution:
Hypertensive emergencies are situations in which grade 3 hypertension (BP>180/110 mmHg) is associated with acute hypertension-mediated organ damage (HMOD).

Treatment of hypertensive emergency depends on the type of end-organ damage present (as shown in the table below). It is treated with rapidly acting intravenous antihypertensive agents.

In hypertensive encephalopathy, the initial goal of therapy is to immediately reduce mean arterial blood (MAP) pressure by no more than 25%. Rapid reduction of blood pressure may lead to reduced cerebral blood flow and result in cerebral infarction.

questions.text:
Which of the following patients would you diagnose as having hypertensive urgency?
  1. A 50-year-old man with a BP of 162/104 mm Hg with no other complaints
  2. A 47-year-old woman with alteration in mental status, nausea, headache, and a BP of 190/120 mm 
  3. A 60-year-old man with a BP of 188/120 mm Hg without any target organ damage
  4. A 55-year-old woman with a BP of 200/140 mm Hg along with papilloedema
questions.solution:
Patient 3 suffers from hypertensive urgency as BP > 180/110 mmHg and end-organ damage is not seen.

Target organ damage is absent in hypertensive urgency but is present in a hypertensive emergency. 

Severe hypertension (grade 3) is generally defined as blood pressure ≥180/110 mmHg. Hypertensive emergency, hypertensive urgency, and malignant hypertension are all forms of severe hypertension.  

Option A: Patient 1 suffers from hypertension. Since BP <180/110 mmHg it is not a hypertensive crisis (urgency or emergency).

Option B: Patient 2 has a BP > 180/110 mmHg along with symptoms of hypertensive encephalopathy. This is an example of a hypertensive emergency as there is severe hypertension with signs or symptoms of hypertensive-mediated organ damage (HMOD). 

Option D: Patient 4 has a BP > 180/110 mm Hg along with papilledema. This is a case of severe hypertension associated with fundoscopic changes (flame hemorrhages, papilloedema) which is suggestive of malignant hypertension. Microangiopathy, DIC, and encephalopathy may also be present.  Fibrinoid necrosis of arterioles and small arteries is seen. The prognosis is very poor if untreated.

Posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES) or acute hypertensive encephalopathy is a rare complication in patients with an acute rise in blood pressure. Due to the acute rise, there is increased cerebral perfusion and edema of the brain. Clinically it is recognized by alteration in mental status, nausea, headache, visual disturbance, seizure, or development of focal neurological deficits.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient who is a known case of hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia presents to the emergency department with a severe headache and vomiting. The patient is agitated and her blood pressure is 220/120 mmHg. Ophthalmoscopy reveals the presence of papilledema. Which of the following antihypertensive is least useful in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The above scenario points towards the diagnosis of malignant hypertension. The drug which is least useful in the management is furosemide(diuretic). 

Volume depletion is common in patients with malignant hypertension, and the administration of a diuretic together with a hypertensive agent can lead to an extreme drop in blood pressure.

Diuretics are generally not recommended for the rapid reduction of blood pressure in patients with hypertensive crises. They are used only in conditions of volume overload such as acute pulmonary edema.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important risk factor for the development of hypertension?
questions.solution:
The most important risk factor for the development of hypertension is obesity.

Hypertension is defined as repeated office systolic blood pressure of ≥ 140 mm Hg and/or diastolic blood pressure of ≥ 90 mm Hg.

Primary/essential hypertension is the leading cause of hypertension in adults. It is caused due to the interaction of genetic factors with various other factors such as diet, sedentary lifestyle, etc. In some people, hypertension may result from renal, endocrine, or adrenal disorders (secondary hypertension).

Risk factors of hypertension can be divided into modifiable and non-modifiable:

Non-modifiable risk factors are:

  1. Age- risk increases with age
  2. Sex- in young and middle-aged adults, the risk is higher in males
  3. Genetic factors- mutation in the genes which encode the components of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, atrial natriuretic peptide, and alpha adducin
  4. Ethnicity

Modifiable risk factors are:

  1. Obesity (most important)
  2. High alcohol intake
  3. High salt intake
  4. Sedentary lifestyle
  5. Stress
  6. Dyslipidemia
  7. Diet low in potassium and calcium

Regularly drinking coffee has been associated with significant increases in systolic and diastolic blood pressure and the development of hypertension.⁠
